HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 13, 1926.

TAU BETA PI WILL
INITIATE THURSDAY
According to an announcement by Frank M. Meredith,
president, Tau Beta Pi, national engineering scholastic
fraternity, will hold its second public initiation of the
year on Thursday, April 15,
at the weekly assembly. The
last public initiation was
held at the assembly of December 10, when David Shafer, Theodore Graser and
Robert White were initiated..
The principal address at
this iniation will be Major
Ezra B. Whitman, Chairman of .the Maryland Public
Service Commission.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 13, 1926.

A HOPKINS GAME
Whenever Hopkins is referred to from the viewpoint of
athletics, the subject of lacrosse is sure to be brought up.
From its earliest years Hopkins has adopted lacrosse as its
own game, and season after season it bas turned out teams
which have upheld the University's reputation of having the
leading lacrosse team of the country.
,One would not expect Hopkins, a small college which
has never overemphasized athletics, to be a constant leader
in any branch of sport, but the old Indian game has gained
such a place in student thought that it has become the one
athletic tradition that Hopkins can boast. Football and
track teams have had their ups and downs, basketball lived
only a short while, and baseball, after a long succession of
lean years, is now peacefully interred; but the high standards of the lacrosse team have changed very little. Some
seasons it may win the championship and some it may not,
but it is always a dangerous contender.
Traditions have grown up around Hopkins lacrosse.
"Father Bill" Schmeisser and others who played about his
time, or before, can tell of• the days before the team had a
coach, when games that were' hopelessly lost were pulled out
of the fire by quick thinking and -the will to win. And the
service flag, honoring the three Hopkins, lacrosse men who
fell in the World War, which the captain hangs on the south
goal during every game, has a deep meaning to all the players, although most of the spectators never notice it.
As a result of the team's long history and the traditions
surrounding it, lacrosse is by far the most popular sport at
Hopkins. Added to these reasons is another, probably not
so creditable, but just as much, in fact we fear more, in keeping with human nature. It is our one opportunity for athletic
glory, and, what is more, sweet revenge. It a great satisfaction to know when spring rolls around that most of the "big"
colleges, which during the football season could eye Hopkins
in a most supercilious manner, could be easily routed by the
Black and Blue stickmen; and then none of them can afford
to treat the Hopkins lacrosse team with anything but the utmost respect and caution.
This year the team is again up to standard. The first
two games, easy ones, it is true, have been won by top-heavy
scores, and our opponents haye yet to score a goal. -Unless
the players suffer from an attack of overconfidence, the prospects for a successful season look bright. But for some
reason interest on the campus seems to be lagging. The season ticket campaign was disappointing, the rooting section
is not as full as it was last fall, and the cheering sounds
weak. The team is strong, but it has a high standard to
uphold and a hard schedule to complete. From now on it
needs every ounce of support that its followers can give.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 13, 1926.

TAU BETA PI WILL
INITIATE THURSDAY
According to an announcement by Frank M. Meredith,
president, Tau Beta Pi, national engineering scholastic
fraternity, will hold its second public initiation of the
year on Thursday, April 15,
at the weekly assembly. The
last public initiation was
held at the assembly of December 10, when David Shafer, Theodore Graser and
Robert White were initiated..
The principal address at
this iniation will be Major
Ezra B. Whitman, Chairman of .the Maryland Public
Service Commission.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 13, 1926.

A HOPKINS GAME
Whenever Hopkins is referred to from the viewpoint of
athletics, the subject of lacrosse is sure to be brought up.
From its earliest years Hopkins has adopted lacrosse as its
own game, and season after season it bas turned out teams
which have upheld the University's reputation of having the
leading lacrosse team of the country.
,One would not expect Hopkins, a small college which
has never overemphasized athletics, to be a constant leader
in any branch of sport, but the old Indian game has gained
such a place in student thought that it has become the one
athletic tradition that Hopkins can boast. Football and
track teams have had their ups and downs, basketball lived
only a short while, and baseball, after a long succession of
lean years, is now peacefully interred; but the high standards of the lacrosse team have changed very little. Some
seasons it may win the championship and some it may not,
but it is always a dangerous contender.
Traditions have grown up around Hopkins lacrosse.
"Father Bill" Schmeisser and others who played about his
time, or before, can tell of• the days before the team had a
coach, when games that were' hopelessly lost were pulled out
of the fire by quick thinking and -the will to win. And the
service flag, honoring the three Hopkins, lacrosse men who
fell in the World War, which the captain hangs on the south
goal during every game, has a deep meaning to all the players, although most of the spectators never notice it.
As a result of the team's long history and the traditions
surrounding it, lacrosse is by far the most popular sport at
Hopkins. Added to these reasons is another, probably not
so creditable, but just as much, in fact we fear more, in keeping with human nature. It is our one opportunity for athletic
glory, and, what is more, sweet revenge. It a great satisfaction to know when spring rolls around that most of the "big"
colleges, which during the football season could eye Hopkins
in a most supercilious manner, could be easily routed by the
Black and Blue stickmen; and then none of them can afford
to treat the Hopkins lacrosse team with anything but the utmost respect and caution.
This year the team is again up to standard. The first
two games, easy ones, it is true, have been won by top-heavy
scores, and our opponents haye yet to score a goal. -Unless
the players suffer from an attack of overconfidence, the prospects for a successful season look bright. But for some
reason interest on the campus seems to be lagging. The season ticket campaign was disappointing, the rooting section
is not as full as it was last fall, and the cheering sounds
weak. The team is strong, but it has a high standard to
uphold and a hard schedule to complete. From now on it
needs every ounce of support that its followers can give.
